editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: Loves crueltie. A tragedy, as it vvas presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private House in Drury Lane. Written by James Shirley Gent.
Loves cruelty.
titleStmt.author: Shirley, James, 1596-1666.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke,

note.p: Reproduction of the original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. div.p: Loves cruelty. A tragedy, as it was presented by her majesty's servants, at the private house in Drury lane.
London, printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke. 1640.

div.head: To the hopeful pair of noble brothers, cornet George porter, and mr. Charles porter.
div.p: The knowledge of your growing virtues, have begotten in all men love, in me admiration, and a desire to serve the manifold obligations I have to the true example of worth captain Endemion porter, instructed me to this presentation of my devoted respects to your noble selves, the true ideas of his virtues. You are so equal in all the attributes of goodness, that it were a difficult endeavour for me to distinguish between your perfections: only noble captain that priority which your birth has allowed you, engages me in the first place to tender my service to yourself, which I imagined could not have been really accomplished, had I not joined your brother in this act of my gratitude to you. Accept therefore heroic pair of brothers, this tender of his best devotions ▪ to you who has no greater ambition than to be esteemed,

closer.signed: The true servant of both your virtues W. a.

div.head: Actus primus.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye sha'not go, indeed you sha'not

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Unless the fault of your poor entertainment

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay now you trespass, and dishonour me
With a suspicion that I can be so
Unjust, as not to acknowledge, you have made
A free, and liberal welcome — but excuse

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Love shall supply, what else hath been defective,
To express my thanks for your kind visit

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis
Business that now ravish me away
By this white hand, which but to kiss, would tempt me
To dwell an age here, I must wait upon
The Duke

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why so you may

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis now my time.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are not tied to such a strict observance
That half an hour can prejudice you, come
I know you may dispense with duty so much.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You may command;

sp.speaker: Cla,
sp.l: Not any thing that shall
Reflect injurious to yourself,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know
you have more charity.

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: If there be other
〈◊〉 that concerns your honour, or your fortune,
〈◊〉 me, I would not by a minute's stay
Be guilty of your wrong, and yet methinks
If there were any thing you might tell me;
〈…〉 thought, that I dare keep from you,
Naughty you may know from whence it breaks,
I have not had a tear, but you have searched
The very spring, come is't some other friend?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O do not so far wound your servant madam
To think my heart can allow any time
For the imagination of another
Woman, did all the goodness of the sex
Conspire in one without you, I should love
My first election, and be blessed to write
All my devotion here; if by the title
Of friend, you understand a man, there is
But one in the whole world I dare call friend,
And I am confident it would trouble me
As much to find a cause that would offend him
As to be guilty of the sin.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If he expected me a day, the crime
Were easily purged, I can presume on him

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This is but little of that character
I have heard your tongue deliver, if his love
Be what you often have proclaimed, trust me
He is a treasure

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Such as both the Indies
Sha'not buy, from me,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Whatthing's rare in him
Above other friends?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: His love his love Clariana;

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That may be found in many

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But not so rich of so exact a nature
All other is but drossy;

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He will venture
his life to advance your cause

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He has don't often
But that is not the thing for which I bosom
Hippolite, I can return full weight
Of blood for his, engage myself to dangers
As high and horrid as he can for me,
But every daring fellow in the street
Can draw a sword, and will for his gay honour
Which sways him more than his religion,
I'th field maintain a good or impious quarrel:
But he is such a one to me, the name
Of friend's too narrow for him, and I want
A word that carries more divinity
To express his love.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are not nice to extol him,
What has he done?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: An act above all friendship
That yet had story, 'bove all recompense
I am not capable of a cause, to quit
His unexampled virtue;

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This is strange

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You will acknowledge when you hear it, and
It does concern you somewhat.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Me, pray let not
My ignorance make me so unhappy, not
To give my thanks if he hath aimed apat
Of courtesy to me, what is't?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He dares not see thee

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dares not see me why
Am I so terrible? does he fear I shall
Transform him? sure Minerva never dressed
My hairs, he should imagine I present
Medusa to him, dares not see me? I
Shoot no infection, nor breathe any mist
That shall corrupt him, what's his reason pray?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Because I love thee, I ha' courted him
As some would do their mistress, but to be
Companion of one visit, and his love
would not permit him

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not to see your friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He loves me so well, that he dares not trust
His frailty with thy sight, whom I have so
Commended, lest before our marriage
Some thing should share in his affection
Which he hath studied to preserve entire
For me, he will not trust his eyes with any
Beauty I love, lest they should stray with too much
Licence, and by degrees corrupt his faith
He knows not what may thieve upon his senses
Or what temptation may rise from him.
To undo us all

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A rare and noble friendship.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is't not Clariana?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He need not fear I shall
Commit a rape upon his friendship, and
A love so just and perfect as his, cannot
With one sight of a woman, armed with more
Beauty than mine, be violated;
He dares not trust his frailty, he has faults
Belike though he be such a miracle
In friendship, pray enjoy him, and by no means
Tempt his soft nature to a crime so great
As seeing me, it shall suffice my love's
To thee inviolable, and what opinion
For your sake, I may modestly allow
The man I never saw, because your friend
Be confident he has it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thar't all sweetness
But I forget my attendance on the Duke
Now you allow my absence, virtuous thoughts
Stream in your bosom.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not one kiss at parting?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let one speak the devotion of your servant
That would but dares not stay, to print a thousand,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Milena. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mil
sp.l: Madam,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is Bellament gone?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Yes madam

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I must see this strange friend, bid make ready
The caroche, and do attend —

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I shall

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dares not trust his frailty with a woman, a fine fellow

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Eubella come to court

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.l: This morning sir
And much graced by the Duke, Sebastian
Her father made a knight

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A knight? Why much good do't him, he's a gentleman may deserve it for his daughter's sake. The Duke has the advantage, he is able to make great men, there is no band to a round pension per annum, or the severe brow of authority, promotion will turn the stomach, we under-sinners o'the commonwealth, ha nothing but our good parts to procure for us, she is like to become game royal then.

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: The Duke pretends she shall be in some place near the Duchess,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: In some near place with the Duke, when the Duchess is in another bed and never dreams on't; she may in time be a gamester, in the mean time the Duke will play at cards with her, and if he chance turn up a coat, the honour shall be hers, and a stock perhaps to set up the precious sin withal, is she not yet ladified?

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: She is in the way to rise

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Thou art mistaken, she is in the way to fall, a handsome gentle woman and new come to court, in the high way to fall too, if any thing will do't, the Duke has taken a course to take in her maiden towns.

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: Did not you love her?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No faith, I cannot properly say I did ever love her, she was too honest, if she have prayed since, she has been sorry for loving me so well, — she was too wise to be a whore, and I was not so much a fool to marry, till my time were come,

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: What time?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Why the fall of the leaf, when my summer is over, the dog-days may do much woe me, marry before one and thirty?
A solecism, 'tis more honourable to be a peep out, then stand at a single game, 'tis neither courtly nor fashionable, and what's become of her wise brother?

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: He cannot do amiss in the general advancement, if his father and sister rise —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He must needs show a high forehead, 'tis such a dog in a wheel, he'll never become a doublet in fashion, he talks as if he had read poetry out of almanacs, and makes a leg like a farmer, I wonder who begotten him?

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: His father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What father? It had been a question, had his mother been a courtier, and not lived and died honest in the country, they that look upon him, and his sister, would never think two, Pollux and Helena, twins, i'th same egg, yet she may be a good hen hereafter and lay, but and he be not addled, he is wiser than his nurse took him for

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: Will you not see 'em in?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.p: I'th garden where the Duke hath been this half hour in private discourse with her

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No I'll back again, I ha' not eaten today, and I dare not look upon an honest woman fasting, 'tis ominous, and we have too many fishdayes already, if the Duke ask for me make some excuse,

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.p: I owe my preferment to you, and you may challenge my services,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Friend whither in such haste

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: If thou lovest me interrupt me not, I dare not stay, there are new things at court, and I ha' not provided a compliment yet I'll see thee anon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Farewell. Wild as the wind some crochet has possessed him
And he is fixed to follow't he but wants
A little pruning, and no courtier
Could grow up more accomplished, I could wish him
An ounce or two of snow to qualify
Some fury in his blood, were there no women
He would be a brave man, but why do I
Trouble myself, that am secure? the Duke.

div.stage: Enter Duke leading Eubella, Sebastian, Bovalda, court.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You are too modest

sp.speaker: Eu
sp.l: That was not wont to be a vice my lord
Or if it be too homely for the court
And out of fashion, with your highness' pardon
I shall be welcome with it, to the place
I came from.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hold that constant my Eubella ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Will you still be ignorant?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is not that your daughter?

sp.speaker: Seb
sp.l: She was

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Has she found another father?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: She has found a misery

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let them tell the marks that lost it and take it again
By my consent

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Bellament

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My lord

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is she not an excellent creature, were't not pity
That so much beauty should be cast away
Upon a thankless woman?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: How sir

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: That wonot use it to her best advantage?
I have been courting this hour for
A smile.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I like not this

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I cannot but congratulate your good fortune

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do not, do not
You ever have been held an honest man.
Pray, do not mock me, it has pleased his grace
To give, me a new name; a ribbon in my forehead

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Sebastian's a forehorse-but would I were to be the Duke's taster,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But there's a price too great set for the honour,
That is my daughter sir, and though I say't
She is yet a virgin, would you part with such
A child to buy a knighthood? bribe at such
Expense for a poor title?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis dark language
I dare not understand you, but you may
Mistake the Duke

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would I did, the way
To be assured is to ask the question sir

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sebastian you put us well in mind, we have forgotten
You have too little testimony of our favour
You shall be captain of our guard

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: How's that? the Duke does love her, I hope not honestly, she was not born to he a Duchess, I have it heaven forgive us, the Duke means to make her own father the pander, 'tis so, he does not use to give such offices for nothing, well go thy ways for a princely ferret, she cannot hold out upon these terms

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I know not what to say, but do you think
She shall be safe here, is the court a sanctuary
For virgins?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Twere better you were both pickled,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It depends upon the prince's chastity
Whose example builds up virtue
Or makes iniquity a trade

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why should you
Be such an enemy to yourself, come fair one
Think who it is that courts you, he that may command.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My life but not my honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your honour? why I offer in exchange
A thousand.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: But not all of value, to
Repurchase mine, when I have sold it to
Your wantonness, remember sir how much,
You may by one black deed, make forfeit of,
Your precious eternity

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No doctrines

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Warrant not so much ill by your example
To those that live beneath you, if you suffer,
That sordid vice reign in your blood, who sha'not
Be afraid to live with virtue

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let a kiss correct this unkind language

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I want patience to see any man kiss
A handsome gentlewoman, and when my own lips
Cannot use their own privilege, I prophesy what will
Become on her, for all her modesty, but dare stay
No longer the sight of so much temptation.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why should any
Promotion charm my honest tongue? I'd rather
Plough my own acres with my innocence
Then have my name advanced by poisoned honour,
He must not whore my daughter

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: I commend.
Your noble soul, but be advised how you
Express your trouble, grief while it is dumb
Doth fret within, but when we give our thoughts
Articulate sound we must distinguish hearers,
Princes are dangerous and carry death
Upon their tongue, I wish you well and speak
My friendly counsel — alas poor gentleman!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come you must wear this jewel, I ha' done,
But you must live at court

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: You will be just
To your own honour, and not give me cause
To curse your entertainment

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You're too scrupulous.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Great sir

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give order for his patent to be drawn
We will create him lord, no honour can
Reward your merit, and the title will
Become the father of this excellent maid

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.l: His mouth's stopped again.
Lord? What does the Duke mean?
No harm to the gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: 2 confidant
sp.p: If these wonot purchase the old man's consent to leave his daughter to his highness' mercy, for he rises that she may be humbled, there are other courses to be thought on, Sebastian has been a soldier, there are quarrels now in the world and Christian wars he were a fit man for a general when he's abroad, the siege at home wonot be so desperate.

sp.speaker: 1. Confidant
sp.l: She must be the court star:

sp.speaker: 2. Confidant
sp.l: Do not you blaze it abroad neither, I do not
Think his grace will acquaint his counsel
With such a cause

sp.p: The old man for ought I see has no stomach to it:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where's Hippolito?

sp.speaker: 1. Confidant
sp.l: I see him this morning.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He is an active courtier, practised in these amorous
Paths, we'll try his skill to win her to our
Close embrace, command him presently wait on us
Bellamenti.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We hear you are to be married.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Ill tell you more hereafter
I do not like the court, and yet I have
His royal word no force shall touch my chastity.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Be resolute for thy honour, I weigh not
The titles he would heap, remember girl
Thy mother's virtue, since thy birth, though noble
Cannot expect his courtship for thyself,
Scorn to be called a lady for his pleasure

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Signior Bovaldo, where's your son?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: So please your highness he's not ith' court
Unless he be in some o'the lobbies, I could
Not examine all: ha? 'tis come about, and the
Father I'll lay my life is laying the law to her,
sp.p: Why was not I a Duke, I have as many titillations, though I be the elder huntsman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You would not thank us for
A law, that none about our court should marry ere we
Choose a wife ourself.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Your grace is pleasant

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Tell me what hast heard of that Eubella?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A very noble character.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What do you call noble?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She's chaste and virtuous

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A virtuous folly but we let her cool
Too much; Eubella

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I know not, still I fear her innocence
Is not enough to guard her, if the Duke
Pursue her viciously, what is a virgin
Against so many flattering temptations?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come fairest.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would you would be pleased my lord

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I am infinitely pleased my lord, with that rare modesty
Sets on this cheek, and with thyself whom we
Have not yet graced sufficiently, our state
Doth want such able honest men, and we
Admit you to our high and secret counsels;
I prophesy the dukedom shall owe much
To your care, and grave directions.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Sebastian and Bovaldo.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Hayda a privy counsellor too.
We are like to have fine smockage on't, virgins will be virgins
If the Duke hold this humour and at such price forestall the market;
A widow will be excellent meat again; he's melancholy,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Shall I be choked with honours and not speak?
Where is my courage, shall a few gay titles
Corrupt a father? Bovaldo thou art reported a
Good fellow.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Would you were as right for your own sake:

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is there no trick to give a man a spirit?
I would be valiant; I dare not talk;

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If you have a mind to quarrel drink.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Well thought on, that shall arm me against all
His flattery shall's to a tavern?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I'll bear you company

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It shall be so; the courts too open,
You shall command Sebastian

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My lord —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: No titles, I'll thither to forget 'em and drink myself into a heat above his conjuration, if there be a spirit in wine I'll swallow it: how is man fallen; that to preserve his name and defend innocence must fly to shame.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I'll lead you sir.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Pretty well I protest la, keep your guard, now sir

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What d'ye think on't, I shall never hit your subtle body

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: A very dextrous proffer, bring it home, everwhile you live
Bring your weapon home,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Again sir

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: But you do not hit me the neat school-way,
I won't give a rush to be killed out of the school-way, you must
Falsify thus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Pretty well, let us breathe

div.stage: Enter page and whispers to his master.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: A gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: That has wooed me sir, if it were possible, to see you first
At some distance

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Is she handsome?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I am no competent judge of beauty, but if you will have
My verdict, she is guilty of a good face.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I'll trouble you no more, I thank you for this exercise

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: The tother bout

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Faces about good, master fencer, my master has some business
You and I will try a vein below

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I would have another thrust I protest

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Not down stairs, what if my master desire to try his skill
With somebody else. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: What means the gentlewoman? I am not to be bought lady.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If you were I have not wealth enough to purchase you.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Do not over value me neither.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I would I had not seen him

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Have you business with me lady?
Expect me in the next room.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I came sir but to see you

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: To see how I do, why I thank you, you are pretty, and I
am'well, what and they were both put together

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You may accuse my modesty that thus rudely, —

sp.speaker: Hi,
sp.l: Nay lady, you cannot offend me that way, I can be as
Rude as you —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What shall I say? d'ye know me sir?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: No good faith not I, but I shall desire to know you any way
You please

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Did you never see me?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: See you? you have a beauty would challenge a remembrance
But sure I was not so happy till this minute

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are a courtier and can flatter.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: And such beauty was made to be flattered

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis a sign it carries not merit enough along to justify it
But 'tis as it is, I cannot help it, yet I could paint if I list

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: The more excellent, I do not love your artificial faces ▪ give
Me one that dates blush, and have but her own colour for't
Here's a cheek hath both cream and strawberry in't a lip with
Cherries that say come eat me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are very bold

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Not so bold as you are welcome, you say you came to see me
And I would satisfy more than one of your senses. I do not
Know your name,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would you do with it, if I told you?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Lay it up precious to memory, and open it as a relic for
Men to do it reverence, at my crowned table drink a health
To the excellent owner, and call it my everlasting Valentine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You would not

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: By this kiss but I would;

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No swearing

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I cannot take too deep an oath in such brisk claret,
Say shall I know it lady?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Excuse me sir
I would not have my name be the tossed for every cup of sack you drink, you wild gallants have no mercy upon gentlewomen, when you are warm i'the canaries

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Why conceal it, I am not in love with a name, and yet I have a grudging, a suspicion, that you ha' pawned or lost it

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Your good name, but let it go, I can tarry till you recover it, I have a bed with in lady, and a couch.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Nothing but to laugh and lie down:

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You are very merry sir. I do like him infinitely, I came for no such purpose, I am not so weary but I can walk

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: There is a gallery to walk after.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I find it true, what you are reported;

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Leave this impertinency, and resolve me again what you
Came hither for

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If you will have the truth, I heard you had a wit, and
A tall one, and I came hither

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: To take it down,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: To try the keenness, I confess it has a pretty edge on't, not altogether so sharp as a razor

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Very good, I shall love this periwinkle.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They say you love women too

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: So they, say, but dare not lie with 'em

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I do not believe you can love any woman truly, that love so many

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Be like you hold some intelligence in my affairs, and have a
Catalogue of all my gennets, I think there be some women
In the world that wish me well, and shan't I
Love 'em again?
The misery on't is, I have never a mistress

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do you not confess many?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Women I grant, some movables, trimmings for a chamber things that serve the turn, but never a mistress one that I would love and honour above all, my lady Paramount, and superintendent Lindabrides and such an empress would thou wert.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sir one from the Duke

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: The Duke; lady I'll wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I dare not name his friend nor who I am
All is not well within me.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p:
Say I attend his grace immediately, lady pardon my former rude trespasses, how unwelcome the cause is that must divorce me from your sweet company I can only imagine, but if you dare
be so gracious, having already so much honoured me to entertain the time of my absence in that gallery, where some pictures may help away the time, you will oblige in the highest degree your servant, as I am a gentleman I will return instantly, and acknowledge the infinite favours:

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The worst is past already, and I am desperately engaged
I have not yet expressed the business sir
That brought me hither, confident of your nobleness
I will expect a while,
Pray send my servant to me
Good fortunes w'ee

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I must not lose her yet,
Lady with your pardon, you shall keep possession a while,
This key will secure you till my return.
sp.p: I hope it will be a fashion shortly for gentlewomen to come home and take their tribute, it will be some relief to our laundresses.

lg.l: Venus grant me a speedy return,
And she scapes me very hard if she have not her come again. Exe.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yet lady have you changed your resolution
May I now hope to be admitted?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Whether?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To your embraces

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Sir I dare not tell you
What I would say, I would some other man
Might plead your argument, I should be plain
And bolder in my answer, in your person
There's something makes me fearful to express
What is behind, another in your name
Would more encourage me to speak.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I'm glad,
I have provided for your modesty
I wonder he's so tedious —

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Whither will these libidinous flames of men.
Pursue poor virgins? does a general fever
Possess their blood? who shall protect the chaste? Enter Hip.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: When would you have me do't?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now she is in presence.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I am not so well
Fortified as I may be an hour hence

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It must not be delayed, I will prepare her.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: I am undone, the poor gentlewoman will be in purgatory when she finds I ha' locked her up, and how to release her I know not, no trick, no device? Bellamento prithee friend go to my lodging, and with this key release a gentlewoman, that expects my return, the Duke has put a scurvy business upon me, kiss her hand for me, and excuse my stay, wot? tell her hereafter I hope we shall meet and not be distracted, my honour is in pawn,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You dare trust me with your tame foul belike, for once
Because there is necessity, I'll take some compassion a your
Pigeons, yet you refused to see my mistress, d'ye remember?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: No quittance now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This is the man lady, d'ye start already? win her to the game —

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I'll do what I can; I may have better luck for you then
For myself, give us opportunity.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Has the Duke pointed him to be his orator

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Lady I bring you news, which you must welcome,
And give me thanks for,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If they be worthy.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: The Duke loves you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: D'ye know sir what you say?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I am not drunk, the Duke, I say does love you

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: O do not use that modest name of love
To apparel sin, I know you meant to tell me
The Duke pursues me with hot lust.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You are a fool,

You understand his meaning, will you be wise, and meet it? such favours are not offered to everybody , I ha' known as handsome a lady as you, would ha' given all the world, and herself too for a bribe to any man that would ha' procured her but a kiss, nay as honest women no dispraise ha' longed for't, and it was mercy in his highness to save the child's nose, you have the whole treasure presented to you, Jupiter in a golden shower falling into your lap entreats to be accepted, come
you must receive him

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The Duke

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Withal the duty of a servant,

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: That's well said

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If he bring virtuous thoughts along with him

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Bring a fiddlestick, come you do not know what it is to be a Duke's mistress, to enjoy the pleasures o'the court to have all heads bare, the knees bow to you, every door fly open as you tread, with your breath to raise this gentleman, pull down that lord, and new mould the tother lady, wear upon a tire the wealth of a province, have all the fashions brought first to you, all courtiers sue to you, tilts and tournaments for you; to have the air you live in, nay your very breath perfumed, the pavement you tread upon kissed, nay your dog, or monkey, not saluted without an officious leg, and some title of reverence. Are you melancholy? A mask is prepared, and music to charm Orpheus himself into a stone, numbers presented to your ear that shall speak the soul of the immortal English Jonson, a scene to take your eye with wonder, now to see a forest move, and the pride of summer brought into a walking wood, in the instant as if the sea had swallowed up the earth, to see waves capering about tall ships, Arion upon a rock playing to the dolphins, the Tritons calling up the sea-nymphs to dance before you: in the height of this rapture a tempest so artificial and sudden in the clouds, with a general darkness and thunder so seeming made to threaten, that you would cry out with the mariners in the work, you cannot scape drowning, in the turning of an eye, these waters ravish into a heaven, glorious and angelical shapes presented, the stars distinctly with their motion and music so enchanting you, that you would wish to be drowned indeed, to dwell in such a happiness

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Fine painted blessings!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
Will you feast, the water shall be summoned to bring in her finny and shell inhabitants, the air shall be unpeopled, and the birds come singing to their sacrifice, banquets shall spread like wildernesses, and present more variety than men can possibly take in surfeits. Are you sick? all the court shall take physic for you,
if but your finger ache, the lords shall put on nightcaps, and happiest that courtier that can first betray how much he suffers with you. Doth not this palace please, the court removes tomorrow: doth the situation distaste, new places are built, and pyramids to put down the Egyptians: will you hunt today? the game is provided and taught news to delight you: will you take the pleasure of the river? the barge attends, music and the mermaids go a long, swans die a long the shores and sing their own dirges: will you spend? the exchequer is yours all honour and offices yours, and which is the crown of all, the Duke himself is yours, whose ambition shall be to make those pleasures lasting, and every day create new ones to delight his mistress.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And yet I think you would not give away
Your right hand for all these, much less present
A poniard to your heart and stab yourself.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I think I should not.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And would you tempt me to do worse?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Worse?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: To sell my honour basely for these vanities

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Vanities?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Mere trifles.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: And you go to that lady, that which you part withal for
All these pleasures, is but a trifle

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Your maidenhead? where is it? whoever saw it? Is it a thing in nature? what marks has it? many have been lost you'd say, whoever found 'em '? and could say and justify, this is such or such a woman's maidenhead? A mere fiction, and yet you think you have such a jewel on't

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: You cannot be so ignorant as you seem

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I tell you what I think.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is chastity and innocence no treasure?
Are holy thoughts and virgin purity
Of so small value? where is your religion?
Were we created men and women to
Have a command and empire o'er the creatures
And shall we lose our privilege our charter
and wilfully degrade ourselves of reason
And piety, to live like beasts, nay be such?
For what name else can we allow ourselves?
Hath it been held in every age a virtue
Rather to suffer death then stain our honour?
Does every sin strike at the soul and wound it
And shall not this, so foul as modesty
Allows no name, affright us? can the Duke
Whose wicked cause you plead, with justice punish
Those by his laws that in this kind offend,
And can he think me innocent, or himself
When he has played the foul adulterer?
Princes are gods on earth and as their virtues
Do shine more exemplary to the world
So they strike more immediately at heaven
When they offend.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I did not trouble you with this divinity,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I see you are a gentleman he favours
Be worthy of his trust, and counsel him
To better ways, his shame is your dishonour;
For every good man suffers with his prince:
Put him in the memory of the holy vow,
When he received his sceptre
He promised then protection to the innocent;
Tell him the punishment in store for lust
This were an angel's office.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: But I'll not do't for a hundred angels, thank you as much
As though I did, that were the trick of a wise courtier, tell
The prince of his faults

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If he have but the seeds of goodness in him
He'll take it well

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: He shall do when I take it upon me,
I am not weary o'my place, thou wouldst make a very fine court
Surgeon — well d'ye hear, you won't do this feat for the
Duke then?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p:
You wonot you're resolved for his sake, why then prithee do't for mine, you told me once you loved me,
I'll take it as a courtesy;

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I never loved your vicious ways;

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: My ways, they sha'not trouble you, I'll take my own
Course, meet him but tonight for my sake and twine with him.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I'll sooner meet with a disease, with death;
You are ignoble, do you urge it as
An argument of my respect to you
To sin against my love?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I shall do no good upon her — were I the Duke, you should
Find another usage.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: A tyrant might do any thingEnter Duke

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now is she moist and supple?
Will she stoop to the impression?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: I told you sir, I was not armed toth' purpose, you took me un provided, at the next bout I may do somewhat, ith' mean time let me counsel you, to let her feed high, she'll never fall low enough else, she must be dieted, if you let her pick her salads, you may fast another lent, and all our pains be not worth an egg at easter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come cruel fair one; we may take the air together.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: So so I'm discharged, now to my guest. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not yet returned? I shall expect too long
He is a handsome gentleman and witty
I must not always walk in clouds, his friend
Must bring us more acquainted, I do love him.
Not yet? his business has much force upon him ▪

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Madam the doors are locked

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What should this mean? he knows me not
I cannot fear betrayingEnter Bellament.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now for this ladybird ha

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Madam 'tis Bellament

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Cupid defend wench, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sure 'tis a dream

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All is at stake, I must be confident, how does my servant?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am wondering

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To see me here I warrant

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is not your name Clariana?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis not sure
You are some other lady without a name
Whom our friend made a prisoner to his chamber,
And cause his business with the Duke detains him
Sent me to kiss your hand and disengage you

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Will you not know me then?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes now I look better on you, you're Claria a
To whom Bellament hath devoted all
His loving honest service, she that gave me
Vows in exchange of mine, if my eyes be not
Unfaithful and delude me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Come I'll take
Your wonder off

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Take it all off together, I ha' not done
My admiration, have I not mistook
My way and fallen upon some other lodging?
Is this your dwelling madam?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: His name, I pray you call the owner

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis so and I am miserable, false Clariana
Oh whither is the faith of women fled!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You'll hear me sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Was't not Hippolito,
Whom I so often did entreat to see her
My friend Hippolito, he would not go with me
To her, that were too public, he had plots
And private meetings, lady he has seen you now
And knows you too,
And how d'ye like him lady, does he not career handsomely
In the devil's saddle? my souls upon a torture

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You'll hear me sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I must be mad come tell me, why do not I kill thee now,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to be a murderer, but if you knew,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know too much but I'll begin with him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To write upon his heart he has abused me,
I like a tame fool must extol his friendship
But never for his sake will I trust man
Nor woman, you have forfeited your souls
There's not a grain of faith nor honesty
In all your sex, you have tongues like the hyena
And only speak us fair to ruin us
You carry springs within your eyes and can
Out weep the crocodile, till our too much pity
Betray us to your merciless devouring.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: When you are temperate enough to hear
The cause that brought me hither happily
You will repent this passion, in which
I must be bold to tell you sir, my honour
Suffers unkindly — and your friends

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Grow not from frail to impudent,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are resolved
To be impatient? when you are collected

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay I will hear, indeed I will, say any thing

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: First then you have no cause to accuse Hippolito
For breach of friendship, had he purposed any
Dishonour to yourself through me, he could not
Be such a fool to send you to his chamber
Who's knowledge, it should last of all the world
Arrive at, if you soberly consider.
He knows not so much of me, as my name;
Think then but with what justice, you have all
This while inveighed against him — for myself
I confess freely sir I made a visit
But innocently and pure from any thought
To injure you; I had a curiosity
To see the man you had so much commended
That was my fault, and I before you came
Accused myself, and could without your fury.
Have chid my modesty enough. Yet sir
You took me in no action of dishonour
My maid was all my company.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But you looked for
One to return, misfortune kept him from you
tell me but this, if thou hast any truth
Could any woman Clariana, that
Would ha' the world but think her virtuous
Suffer herself to be locked up suspiciously
Within a stranger's lodging,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By all goodness
It was without my knowledge, I was weary
Expecting him, and meaning to depart;
Some minutes ere you came my servant told me
I was a prisoner, you have all the story
Which cannot, if but weighed with reason
Carry a crime like yours

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Like mine?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I ha' said it
'Tis you have made a greater fault than I,
With so much violence to condemn before
You know the offence, and I must tell you sir
But that my love is grounded upon virtue,
This were enough to stagger my affection
Rail at your mistress but for going abroad
To see your friend? so just a one? I see
You will be jealous when we are married.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Never, you have awaked my honour lady
I dare believe and ask thy pardon, trust me
I will command my passions hereafter
And if thou but consent, give proof, all jealousy
Is flown away, we'll marry instantly
Should he retain a thought not square of her
This will correct all, he is here, no word
Of discontent, put all off merrily.
Let's kissEnter Hip.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How now, he won't serve me so?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We are acquainted and now you have seen
My mistress, I shall hope, we may enjoy
Your company hereafter,

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Ha, your mistress?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine. Clariana

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis my name

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Come sh'as told me all
I'll take her word nothing has passed offensive,
Salute her now as mine, the character
I gave her, and thy resolution
Not to see her, engaged her to this travel

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: May I be confident, you have forgiven
My wild discourse, my studies shall hereafter
Bend all to serve you nobly

sp.speaker: Cla
sp.l: There is cause that I should beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We'll not part.
Now till the priest hath made all perfect

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I'll assist the clerk

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have power to steer me

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hymen light up thy torches, woods of pine
Should be cut up to make thy altars shine. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We might with more discretion sent for wine ▪
To my own lodgings.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ever while you live drink wine at the fountain

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Here I am not known, let nobody interrupt us

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let it be rich and sparkling, my precious varlet, and how
And how go things at court?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: After a cup or two I'll tell thee.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I would Hippolito were here, he's a good fellow, and takes
After his father, the Duke makes much on him

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Here's a good health to him

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let it come, I am glad to see you sociable, come to the
City and leave purchasing, dusty acres

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The same justice that mine had.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And it were as deep as an usurer's conscience,
My boy should have't

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: Will't please you gentlemen to hear any music.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Shall have any?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: By no means, it takes from our own mirth

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Be gone then.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: A very good song, and please you

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yet again, will you have your occupation broke about
Your head?

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.l: I'll make you laugh gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I'll make you cry and tune your voice to the lamentation
Of o my fiddle, if you remove not presently.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is the trick of taverns, when men desire to be private.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Come whom shall we now remember? here's to your mistress

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A mistress at my years?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Till threescore you're allowed, I never wore more favours at one and twenty, this ribbon came from a countess, this lock I wear for a young lady's sake, this touch was the fall of a gentlewoman's fan that is new come to court

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: New come to court? I'll pray for her, is she virtuous?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And she be, there is hope the courtiers may convert her, here's
To her firstEnter juggler.

sp.speaker: Juggler
sp.l: Gentlemen will you see a jackanapes?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How many is there of you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yet more o'these rascals?

sp.speaker: Juggler
sp.l: I can show you very fine tricks

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Prithee hocus-pocus , keep thy granam's huckle bone.
And leave us.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Presto be gone, or I'll teach you a trick for your jackanapes
Learning, they will be deceived that choose a tavern for privacy

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Come our blood cools; here's to your fair daughter

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Poor girl, I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I do not flatter you, but you may be proud, I say no more

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your daughter, she's a handsome gentlewoman, there be
Worse faces at court;

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Her complexion is natural, she has no trick of art
A little breeding she has had; and some precepts to guard her honesty

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Honesty where is it?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It should be everywhere

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Take heed what you say, lest you be made to justify it
honesty everywhere ?
Here's to you, come.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I speak Bonaldo what I think, and it would be no
Dishonour to the greatest to be the first examples.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If all were of your mind who should thrive in this world?
Pledge me
How shall christians' behave themselves in great offices?
sp.p: Or under-clerks purchase honesty? but one term were enough to undo the city, the court were but in ill case if great men should stand upon't, for the country, 'tis bought and sold every market day.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Name it

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To the Duke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: The Duke, he does not love me

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No Bovaldo he does not,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He loves your daughter —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Tis not princely, nay I shall dare to tell him so, but
To his health.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Let it come, methinks he is a very fine gentleman,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I begin to be warm already.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And one that loves a wench as well —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: As ill thou wouldst say?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: As ill as I, let it be so, I were no good subject to deny it
To his highness.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou knewest me a gentleman

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Are you not so still?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No I'm a knight, a lord I know not what,
I'm lost within a wilderness of names
But I will be myself again — the tother cup.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: 'Tis welcome, shall we double our files?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This skirmish will do well

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Charge me home then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now I could talk methinks .
I will not prostitute Eubella for
The wealth of his whole dukedom, there's no honour
To a noble conscience, he is the greatest coward.
Dares not be honest.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Right, if a man dares not be honest he is a coward
But he that dares be dishonest,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Dares cut his father's throat

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: A pretty fellow here's to you again; shall's have a wench? now am I addicted to embrace any thing in the likeness of a woman, o for a chambermaid to wrestle withal; send for a brace of basilisks, thou hast no spirit no masculine virtue, now could I o'er run the whole country of the Amazons. Here's to a Penthesilea bear up my valiant Myrmidon and we will do such feats shall make the Trojans wonder at our backs and bring dame Helen to us.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I prithee leave this humour, 'tis not generous,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How not generous take heed what you say

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I sha'not eat my words

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then drink your drink,
Now Troy burns blue, whereas Hecuba?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou art all for wenching,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Upon a condition I will drink to thee

No, no, thou wot not do so much, and a man should die for a lift a'the leg: the Duke has a great mind to thy daughter, he is but mortal flesh and blood, there be subjects that have as sound bodies no dispraise to his excellency.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: D'ye not fear to talk thus?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Fear? would any durst send to me such
A virgin pinnace, rigged and gay with all flags.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is uncivil, and I shall tell Bonaldo

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Nay nay, thou art so waspish, if a friend desired a courtesy, that is in fashion; because the Duke —

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You're too bold, and forget yourself, I am
Ashamed of this converse; because the Duke?
Did his hand grasp the sceptres of the world
And would propound 'em all to buy the honour
Of my Eubella, I would scorn his salary
And tell him he were poorer in his soul
Then he that feeds ith' hospital, I'm armed
And shall grow very angry with your humour
Which ere it named my daughter carried wickedness
enough, but in her cause I am easily
Provoked to teach that tongue repentance dares
Traduce her whiteness, I allow a mirth
But do not love this madness, and if I
Might counsel you, there is a way to quench
These wild licentious flames, earnest of those
Our souls shall feel hereafter, we are both
In years, and should look out our winding sheet
Not women,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Boy I'll pay the reckoning; be honest and see what will
Come on't
I'll seek out my son Hippolito.
He'll be ruled by me, here's a coil about a tassel gentle

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He's drunk already
That which has raised me but to noble anger
Is his distraction, there's for your wine
Now to the wanton Duke, heaven let him see
His shame and know, great men that practise lust
Both kill their body and corrupt their dust,
Let him fret do what he can,
The world shall call, Sebastian honest man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Had I but one thing that did touch on honour
My friendship, and is that diseased already
And languishing? was it for this I would not
See her that I might trespass with more guilt
When she was married? are not other women
As fair and tempting? or am I hurried
By violence of my fate to love her best
That should be most a stranger? and does she
Meet my modest flame? nay must the tapers
Sacred to Hymen light us to our sins?
Lust was too early up in both, o man
O woman! that our fires had kissed like lightning
Which doth no sooner blaze but is extinct, she's here.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Where's your master?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: There he is madam

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do you walk so melancholy sir?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I was collecting myself about some business
Must be dispatched this morning, sirrah pray
The groom make ready my horse

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not yet
You do not mean to leave me o'the sudden?
I am alone, my husband is at court,
Pray rob me not of all my company,
I shall not think upon his absence, with
So much sorrow if you make me happy
With your society.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: There's the devil already, I cannot leave her
My boy may go howsoever. Exit. page

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O Hippolito
If you have used no charms but simple courtship,
Perhaps you may condemn me in your thoughts
That I so soon (Not studying the ways
Of cunning to disguise my love, which other
Women have practised, and would well become
The modesty of a wife) declare myself
At your dispose, but I suspect you have
Some command more than natural, I have heard
There have been too much witchcraft exercised
To make poor women dote

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: You are not serious
In what you say? I hope you do not take me
For such a juggler? if you think I practise

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That look acquits you, then at my nativity
Some powerful star reigned, I have heard astrologers
Talk much of Venus

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: And of Mars when they are
In conjunction, they incline us mortals
Strangely to love and lie with one another

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am ignorant
What influence we have from them, but I
Am sure, something has strangely wrought on me

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: As how madam?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why to love, I know not home,
You know my meaning, but truth witness with me
When first I saw your person I gave up
My liberty, methought I loved you strangely.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I had desires too I could not justify
But knowledge that you were my friends, for that time
All loose fires, but love that swayed you, then quenched
And kept your thoughts longing, met with my heart
And scald it up for you, yet when I think on Bellament.
There's wrestlings in my blood.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Just when I think on him 'tis so with mine,
That love should be so equal, dost not stir you
Sometimes to think of former vows? Nay I do dream
Sometimes of being surprised in thy dear arms
And then methinks I weep, and sigh and wake.
With my own groans.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I never dream of that

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is my foolish fancy, yet such fears
Should waking never trouble me, those lovers
That have not art to hide, and to secure
Their amorous thefts, deserve to be revealed:

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Sure there's no woman in the world but this
Could have such power against my friend, each syllable
Renews her force upon me,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I beseech you
Although a storm hath thrown me on your shore
Have not so little charity to think
I should accept of safety on another,
It is not possible any but yourself
Withal the magic of his tongue or fortunes
Could bribe me from Bellament, if I fall
For too much loving you, your mercy may
Interpret fairly, by these tears

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Sir your horse is ready

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I sha'not go yet, lady if you please
We'll walk a turn ith' garden. Eeunt.

sp.speaker: Groom -
sp.l: Hark you my small friend, without offence is not your
master a —

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: What

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: I would have another word for a whoremaster

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: How my dirty rubber of horse heels

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Nay I do not say he is, I do but ask, whether he be or no, be not angry demi-lance, there be as good gentlemen as he, that love a wench.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Why is your mistress a wench?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: My mistress you didapper

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I do not say she is, I do but ask whether she be or no, there be as handsome creatures none dispraised, that take money for their warren, have I answered you my bold merchant of dung in a wheel barrow?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: How now jackalent is shreds of satin, I shall swing you with a horse-rod, you whippet

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Go meddle with your master's gelding, and cheat him in the provender to keep you in perpetual pots of ale, when you entertain the kitchenmaid in the hayloft, talk of my master?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Meddle with my mistress?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Yes I'll speak to her to allow you a less proportion of clean straw to rub boots and lie in sirrah, you think you are at rack and manger, when you divide beans with the horses and help to foul the stable

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Sirrah whelp that has eaten knotgrass, do not provoke me lest I fetch a smith and curry your thin sides

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Mine you bean-shifter, would you durst no better ride booty at the horse match or cousin your master ith' next parcel of oats, I fear you not my canvas servingman with half a livery, groom o'the stable once removed from the farrier.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What at difference?
Both no not we madam.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Sirrah come hither.
Entreat my father meet me at court,

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I shall sir

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: There's no haste for my nag yet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: About your business sira.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p:
My business is below stairs, and with a gelding, what he
may prove I know not well, what I think I will keep to myself, my lady may be honest enough, but he that is born to be a cuckold shall never die a bachelor. Exit.
sp.stage: A song which done. Enter Sebastian and courtiers.

lg.l: Duke my lord you are welcome

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Give me leave to tell
Your highness I suspect it.
Why should a prince dissemble?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This dialect becomes you not

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir sir I must be honest

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Father

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Eubella express thy duty
To him thou callest a father, for thy own
Sake leave this place, the court's a fire

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How sir

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Canst thou not see the flames that threaten thee?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sebastian's wild

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But you would make her tame, look look Eubella
The Duke himself burns, do not his eyes spark
With lust, his very breath will blast thee

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I fear this will be dangerous, good sir,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If yet thou hast not lost thy innocence
I charge thee, by thy mother's memory
And colder ashes, keep thyself unstained
Let no temptation corrupt a thought
Thou'rt richer in thy chastity, than all
The Kings of earth can make thee, if thou fall
Thou killest my heart

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: All this for thy sake we forbear to punish,
But you should know my lord

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Lord me no lords
I groan under the burden of your honours
And here resign all, give me but my daughter

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Let not your passion strangle thus your reason

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let not a sin so black as lust degrade
A prince and register thy dishonoured name
With foul adulteries

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You're very bold

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would preserve the name of our yet honest family
I fear she is o'er come already, I do not like her silence.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To take off your fears
Although we need not give you satisfaction,
By this white brow, she is as pure as when
She came to court.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O let Sebastian fall
Lower sir, I beseech you tread upon me
So you will still be honest to my child,
She is all my comfort

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Rise.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But will you not
Hereafter study to betray her innocence?
Or give her licence to return with me?
I'll ask no more assurance, grant but this
And when we are at home, it shall oblige us
Beside the duties we already owe
In heart to pray for you

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We are not pleased, she should depart.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Then I'll unthank your goodness
And dare thus boldy tell your highness, laws
Are most unjust that punish petty thieves
And let the great ones scape,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We are yet patient.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Dear sir

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Princes may take our children from us, not
To advance but kill their names, corrupt their virtues;
When needy men, that steal to feed their lives
Are doomed to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Take the frantic hence.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Take hence the ravisher

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.l: Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Although he ravish not Eubella
From herself, yet he does ravish
A daughter from her father, and I'll voice it
Through every street, I am not bound to whisper
When griefs so loud within me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Place him where his noise may make his own headache not others,
This liberty of tongue shall be corrected

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It will but spread thy infamy, when men
Shall speak my cause, and thy lasciviousness
Which I will tell so often to the stones
The vault shall be ashamed to echo thee Eubella

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away with him

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do bury me alive, be strong Eubella
And let not death by my example shake thee.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: This may incline her, do not weep Eubella
They are not worth a tear, yet 'tis within
Thy power to ransom their bold heads, were they
Humbled tooth block, this pity shows a child
But princes lose their awe that are too mild.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where's your lady?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: In her chamber.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Who's with her?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: None but the gentleman you left here

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hippolito? I wonot have so base a thought — ilt to 'em,
Yet, you may go and say I am returned and wish her presence.
Ha? there is something busy with my brainExit. Ser.
And in the shape of jealousy presents
A thousand fears, they have been very loving
Since we were married; thou soul's corrupter
Who sent thee to me? to distract my peace,
Be gone, be gone, and scatter thy foul seeds ▪
Upon a ground that will be fruitful to thee.
The innocence I carry in my breast
Arms me against the thoughts of others treason,
My friend, my wife? the very names are sacred
And like the heads of saints, and holy martyrs
Invested with such glorious beams they strike
Conspiracy blind, how now, what's in thy face? Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O sir?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Would you could understand without my tongue

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How does thy lady

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lady is —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha ▪ why dost pause villain? answer me

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Alas I know not with what words to tell you
Would I had never seen her, or you never
Married her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha? stay there, shall I trust thee now fury? but speak, and
Be not tedious, what is my lady doing upon thy life?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Alas sir it will make you mad.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Speak or never speak again, I am prepared

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Pardon my unhappiness to deliver then
A truth that will distract you, you have now
Nor friend nor wife

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Are they both dead?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes dead to honour, finding her chamber locked
I know not what did prompt me to make use
Of a small cranny, where I beheld 'em both,
I want modest language
To tell how they are fallen, and yet too soon
I know you cannot choose but understand me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How long hast thou been a raven?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good sir collect yourself,
'Tis my misfortune and no fault to be
The sad reporter

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do I live still?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: And shall I hope long

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou'rt most uncharitable, if thou hadst loved
Thy master thou wouldst wish him happiness
Which all life denies, is my composition
So hard, a sorrow great and high like this
Cannot dissolve it? wonot my heart break
With this? then melt it some celestial fire,
In pity of my sufferings some cloud
Of rain, since my own eyes refuse to drown me,
Fall and o'erwhelm this miserable island

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Can this be possible? be sure they are devils
Or I shall find such a new hell for thee —

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I would it were not true

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I would it were not true

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Some merciful whirlwind snatch this burden up
And carry it into some wilderness:
Leave not
If it were possible the mention
Of what I was behind, the wolves are honester
Than mankind is to man, I prithee kill me
I kneel to be destroyed, it is thy duty;
When thou shalt tell the world my wretched story
And what soul killing and devouring griefs
Thy good hand rid me of, it shall acquit thee
And call thy murder charity

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good sir

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O whither shall I run to find a friend
Will do the gentle office to dispatch me
Without my own hand?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Rather live to take
Justice upon their perjuries.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good man.
My better angel how had I forgotten
Myself? Coward to think of dying yet.
Who would put confidence in heaven hereafter.
If it should suffer me depart the world
Without revenge, and that my own upon 'em.
Come draw, take my sword, I will be double armed ▪
I charge thee by my duty, or thy life
If that be more, stay you at bottom of
The stairs, while I ascend their sinful chamber
And if my pistol miss his treacherous heart
He has no way to pass but on thy sword,
The place gives such advantage that with
Safety thou mayst command his life.
Kill him with loss compunction than a witch
Fleas a dead infant for his skin to perfect
A hellish incantation, thou wilt do't?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll do my best he 〈◊〉 scape

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Wife, friend,
You hang like ulcers on me, I am bound
to cut you from my heart to cure my wound.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Hippolito and Clariana upon a bed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What pity 'tis these pleasures are not lawful.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Lawful? that would take much from the delight
And value, I have heard some gentlemen,
That want no venison of their own,
Swear they had rather strike their neighbours dear
Then hunt in their own park, what we possess
We keep for our necessity, not game,
Or wearied with enjoying give't a way
To purchase thanks abroad.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: For all that madam, there is danger in some purlieus, and when the keeper is none of the wisest, their bolts are sooner shot, I like the sport, but would not be taken at the dear stealing, yet for such a do as thou art, I would venture —

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: 'Tis no glory to take a town without some hazard, that victory is sweetest which is got in the face of danger, when the very cannons are hoarse with clamour, than the bold soldier goes on and thinks the noise loud music to him, give me the man that fears no colours, was there ever any thing worth the enjoying that came easily and without trouble to us? what makes a maidenhead the richer purchase think you? but I am married and my husband is your friend

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Prithee no more o'that

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
No more o'that, in my conscience you are fearful this is the ballad right. Courtier heigh courtier ho, wilt thou be my true love, no no no, fie upon't. I should name my husband often to arm and fortify ourselves ▪ I confess, I do not wish him here, perhaps he would do some mischief, and hinder another meeting, but if he were present now, and should see us kiss, for and he 'Were ten husbands, I would trust his eyes no further, what
could he say? for he did but kiss her, for he did but kiss her, and so let her go: come for shame be more sprightly, I have as much reason to look about, and play my game wisely, if my cards were considered.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Yet you are very confident.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: He does use to keep his word, I know he'll not return this two hours, come we are secure, prithee let's talk oh something else.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Of death.
Are ye untwined?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Are we betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You did not look for me — your sword is of no use, d'ye see pity your own damnations; and obey me, get into that closet no considering, it must be done: so you are fast, now lady lechery dress you the bed a little, and lay the pillows handsomely bestir you

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Upon my knees —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No petitioning, you can sing, quickly or — so so, you sirrah at the bottom of the stairs, come up. Be wise and do not kneel nor whimper. Enter servant.

lg.l: Now sirrah speak and tell me truly
Or I'll search every corner of thy soul
Why didst thou play the villain, thus to mock me
With expectation to find my wife

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Hold sir I beseech you

sp.speaker: Bël.
sp.l: What devil did instruct thee to disquiet
My heart, secure and confident of their honours
As conscious of my own, no head but mine
To bruise with jealousy, where is he? show me
Or take into thy bosom what my vows
Had fixed for him and her

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: If these be eyes I saw 'em '

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If these be eyes, is that your proof, lay such
A cause upon the strength of a weak sense
That is a thousand ways deceived, your eyes!
O Clariana, this impudent slave
with such a cunning face, told me thou wert
Naught, locked in the lustful arms of base
Hippolito, my friend, my honest friend.
One that commands not his own life so much
As I, that would not for a monarchy
Do me the least disgrace, hast found him villain?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll look under the bed sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And I believed him too, and had I found
But the least point of such a sin, within
Thy chamber, furies should appear more tame
Than Bellament, hell should not have malice.
Enough to add to my revenge, but pardon.
My easy credulous nature, I confess
A fault, for had I loved thee nobly as
Became our holy vows, our vows Clariana
To which we called the angels, I should never
Have entertained one thought against thy chastity
But this slave shall repent it.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Hold, I beseech you sir? by my life I thought
I saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thought? is that excuse

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Good sir, I'll never trust my own eyes after this
There was deceptio visus. O be merciful

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: None but her honour, and my friends to poison?
Had this report not first arrived at me
How had we all been shamed — dost thou kneel too
Nay then I must forgive him, rise my honest
My dearest Clariana — but I shall hear
You will be prating of it, if one syllable
Come to my ear let fall by thee, that touches
But thy suspicion, I'll ha' thy tongue
And heart.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Cut me into a thousand pieces. Madam your pardon
How was I cozened

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be gone and thank her goodness thou dost live
But do not dare to be so desperate
To come within my eye reach till I call thee

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll not come near you, I'll bury myself in the cellar. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: So so ▪ now sir you may come forth again
Nor do you my most excellent whore, think
There is no storm to follow — keep your distance
You have had a feast, a merry one, the shot
Is now to be discharged, what do you expect?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Death, from that hand, I apprehend no mercy
Not have I so much innocence to hope
You will delay your justice,, were I armed
With power to resist, I should add more
Offences by defending of this life
That has so basely injured you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Treacherous serpent

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: With this I have sometime relieved your valour
And had no pity of my blood, but then
I was a friend, in such a cause as this
I have no arm no weapon, not, if I
Were sure the bullet would decline my heart.
It does beget a cowardice to think
How I am fallen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O pardon

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pardon with what conscience canst thou ask it?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You showed a charity above my hope
By giving a few minutes for my prayer,
Which shows you had no meaning to destroy
The soul, 'twas rare compassion, but if you
Could possibly forgive?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How forgive

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I say if it were possible you could
Remit so foul (In me the black'st) offence
Not for the love I have to number days
But by some noble service, to wash off
This shame, this leprosy upon my name

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ha you found it now.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I have but vainly interrupt your fury
You cannot must not pardon it, such mercy
Becomes not an Italian.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Miserable woman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O sir, it was my first offence, what woman is
without some stain? if all that in this kind
Have sinned, had met with present death you would
Not find some names, that now shine gloriously
Within the catalogue of saints, my soul
Is full of shame and tears.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tell me Clariana ▪
Still I shall hit upon thy name, how couldst thou
Use me so cruelly? did I want youth
And spring about me were my embraces cold
Frost in my blood? or in thy bed was I
Conveyed a snowball, rolled up the children
Do to play with winter, did I not affect thee
Beyond all the comfort of the world?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And thou whom best of all mankind I loved
Whose friendship took up my whole heart till she
Came in a wife, yet then thou hadst a seat
One small degree below her, when this shall be
The talk of Ferrara who shall trust his friend
For thy sake, or at the mention of thy name
For swear ever to marry

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Noble sir.
It is within your power

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To kill you both

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I am prepared so well
As this short time will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis yet within your power to silence all,
What is already done should we turn fountains
We heartily may grieve for, not repair,
The world can have no knowledge of our trespass
Nor your dishonour, if you call it so
Unless you tell it, you have nobly sir
Secured all shame at home, which has won more
Repentance from me than my tears, go on
Increase that piety, and be not you
The trumpet of their infamy abroad
Whose lives hereafter may be spent with such
Religious sorrow for offending you
that you may not repent to have forgiven.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Shall I be won with foolish pity?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Our death will gain you nothing, but the fear
You sha'not keep your own life

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Or if blood
Must only satisfy, let your sword here
Bathe in revenge, the greatest sinner kill
If men were not, what woman could be ill.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your fears thus vanish, I delight not in
The bloody sacrify, live both.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A miracle

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But I'll do more than kill you — take my love off.
I do desire never to see you more,
Nor will I be a courtier to occasion
Meeting hereafter, what is done is circled
Within our knowledge, pray, farewell, for you
I do desire never to bed thee more
I'll force some smiles to keep suspicion off
But fear I never shall love heartily
Again, thou hast undone me here, Clariana
And yet I wonot wish thee dead for this
Repent and when I die ask for a kiss. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Not at the court? why he desired I should meet him here

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: The Duke hath often asked for him

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: He waits well in the mean time, who in the name of wantonness keeps him away, I know 'tis a wench, 'tis a perilous boy, my own son to a hair, and he should not love a woman I would disinherit him, for I am of opinion an atheist sometime is better than an eunuch, and yet cannot the court find him game enough, but he must leap the pale and straggle so far for venison, that the Duke must hunt after him; and he were not my own flesh and blood, I would counsel him to marry, but they are dangerous, and a disease is more curable than a wife, for she indeed is a hectic fever although I buried mine seven year ago, yet I feel a grudging of her still, and for a need could guess at the change of weather by the knowledge her noise has infused into my bones.

sp.speaker: Courtier
sp.p: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Some one look out Hippolito

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: If please your grace let it be my employment

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Signior Bonaldo?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Your highness' humble servant ▪ I am sorry my son should be absent, when your grace has service for him, but I'll find him out, I am acquainted with two or three of his haunts I know a tavern is next door to a —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: To a what?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: It has a course name

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: No matter:

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: To a bawdy-house

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: That's not impossible

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: To find him there, I cannot help it?

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.p: He loves him the better for't

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: 'Tis a trick he learned in France sir, where your nobility practice, he will leave it, when capering and kissing are out of fashion with gentlemen

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: O he is young, I have heard you were as wild at his years,

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: And wilder too I should be sorry else

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: I had never broke my wife's heart else, with supping abroad and midnight revels ▪ I should ha' been troubled with her till this time

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: She was a shrew it seems? but you promise actively still?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not much for the cross point,
But with your highness' licence, I'll find out Hippolito
To attend your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Good signiorExit.
A blunt honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.p: He does not boast much honesty, with your pardon sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I like the freedom of his discourse, but see Hippolito

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I must not appear melancholy

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.l: Signior the Duke expects you

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: His grace's humble creature

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.l: Now is he come from some vaulting school I'll lay my life,
he is a pretty gentleman 'tis pity that nothing can persuade him from the flesh.

sp.speaker: 2. C.
sp.l: The Duke employs him.

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.l: I leiger at home

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Both in prison

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Both.
We all know Eubella, her father is committed to prison for being
