To free on's tongue.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Be confident I will prevail, I have a new spell for her

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be speedy and be fortunate, she is in that chamber
Return with her consent to love and be
What the Duke's power can make thee.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You too much honour me

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come gentleman.

div.stage: Hippo. seems to open a chamber door and brings forth Eubel.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Lady, I am sent to know your full and final resolution touching the business the Duke propounded, though your father be shut up yet change of air is fitter for your complexion, the Duke is a gentleman that may command in these parts 'tis not for want of provision, the Duke has a mind to cut up your virginity.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If this be your affair sir, tell the Duke
Eubella is a rock.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That's very hard

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: His mermaids cannot win me with their songs
Nor all his tempests shake me

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Stay a little
There's something more in my commission

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Hippolito
I now have argument to think you were
Not born a gentleman, something, here is witness
I pity thee, this is no noble office

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You mean a pander it has been a thriving way for some,
But I am employed by his grace.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Shall fear or flattery
Corrupt a generous soul? I am a woman
The weakest of a thousand yet I dare
Give man example, rather to be sacrificed.
Then betray virtue's cause, we give our life
to grow again, from our own funeral pile
Like the Assyrian bird.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: Thou hast so rich
A stock of goodness, were all other women
Vicious, thou mightst impart enough to make
The whole sex white again, and leave thyself
One degree less than angel: canst thou pardon
That I have tempted thee so far? thy hand
To give it a religious kiss, when next
My tongue is orator in so foul a cause
The argument itself turn a disease
And eat it to the root. I am changed Eubella
And more to try thy strength then to o'ercome
I speak now for the Duke, keep still thy thoughts
Devout to honour, after I have studied
A year's repentance for my wrongs to thee,
I will presume to say I love Eubella

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: But hath Hippolito no other meaning?
I understand, and take some joy to hear this language

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The first proof of my conversion
Shall be to tell the Duke he has done ill
To court thee sinfullyEnter Duke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: B Eu.
sp.l: Pray do not mock, if you knew how much,
Delight heaven takes to hear you speak so well
To the distressed Eubella.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: By this lip
If my profane touch make thee not offended
There is no good I will not act, nor ill
I will not suffer to deserve thy love
But I am miserable and cannot merit
I have not been at home these many years
Yet I will call my conscience to account
For all, and throw myself upon heaven's charity,
Why dost thou weep?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My joy can wear no other livery
Than tears, and confident all this is truth
I cannot keep it in, you shall dispose
Eubella's heart.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Then here I take it in
To my possession

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Villain strumpet

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Sir, here are none such I can assure your highness

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is this your faith to me?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I never did you.
True service till this minute, and I dare
Now tell you, though you cut my head off, 'tis
Not justice to pursue the ruin of
A harmless maid

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Traitor

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Call me some name, I understand my lord
This virgin now is mine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Your whore

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: This cannot make me yet forget your person

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By my dukedom

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: The more you vex the more we grow together
In honour and chaste love

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You speak as if
You were to be her husband,

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: 'Tis a title a prince should be ambitious of.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Very fine
Do you consent too, to be called his wife?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If he dare make me such there is no second
My heart affects.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is't come to this? then hear what I determine

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Sir consider

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I have considered do not interrupt me
Too morrow if I live I'll see you both
Married, thou excellent maid forgive my passion,
Accept him freely, thou hast overcome
With chastity, and taught me to be a prince
Which character, my lust had near defaced
Release Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: What duty can poor Eubella pay?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more, good deeds reward themselves, how have we slept.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: This exceeds all your favours ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Cherish my gift Hippolito, she is a wife for the best prince, no honour can be enough to satisfy thy virtue. Exit,

sp.speaker: Confidant
sp.p: Here's a strange whirl, I do not like it, if the Duke continue this mind, we must all be honest.

sp.speaker: 2. Confidant
sp.l: Who can help it?

div.stage: Enter Bellament and Bonaldo at several doors.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Save you signior is my son here?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He was here very lately, too late

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You do not answer as you were wont,
I ask for Hippolito, your friend,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And did not I answer you?
Cry you mercy signior, indeed he is not here

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How is it with your beauteous Clariana?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She's well

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Pray commend my service to her

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What said ye?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nothing but my service to your lady

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O I thank you, pray stay, and tell me how I look.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Look?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: They will persuade me within I am not well
I must confess there is some cause of melancholy
Within me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I guest so at first sight, may I presume to ask it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And yet does not concern me in a higher nature than
My friend, a scurvy chance late happened to him
One that he loved most dear, you will scarce
Believe, made him a cuckold

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: That all?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That all. D'ye understand what I have said?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Yes a friend was made a cuckold by a friend
He did his wife and him a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Go home and pray, you're in a desperate state
This is enough to weigh thee down to hell

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am not of your mind, and I had don't myself, I should
Never had so much despair as to hang myself, why 'tis as
common as shifting a trencher

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But hark you sir, howe'er you talk you cannot in your judgement think so, are you married?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What d'ye see in my forehead you should think me so miserable?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll tell you then, what a wife is, or should be

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I can tell you, what they should be,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: They should be honest and love their husbands, and for their sakes their bastards, which if they understand they are bound, to keep, because their ill conditions drive us a broad to get 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No, hear me.
A wife is man's best piece, who till he marries
Wants making up, she is the shrine to which
Nature doth send us forth on pilgrimage,
She was a scion taken from that tree
Into which if she have no second grafting
The world can have no fruit, she is man's
Arithmetic which teaches him to number
And multiply himself in his own children,
She is the good man's paradise, and the bad's
First step to heaven, a treasure which who wants
Cannot be trusted to posterity
Nor pay his own debts, she is a golden sentence
Writ by our maker, which the angels may
Discourse of, only men know how to use
And none but devils violate

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: All this you'll justify a wife

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now tell me signior what punishment
That man deserves, that should deface or steal
This wealth away.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How mean you in the way of lying with her?
I am of my first opinion, there is not much treason
In't, if she be handsome

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But is there no respect of friendship to be observed?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Nor kindred much in such a case

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Would you not chide your son that should abuse his
Dear friends wife or mistress?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Yes if he should abuse her, but if he did but lie with her I should commend him, make the case your own would you deny a friend that wanted linen the courtesy of your clean shirt? A woman is a more necessary wearing, and yet never the worse for't

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Away thou wot infect my dwelling else,
To what a monster, is man grown

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Fare you well sir, I ha' but answered to your questions

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Cynic I'll hold thy lantern now, and go with thee
Through Athens and the world to find one man
That's honest. Enter page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: My master remembers his humble service

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To me? I'd rather thank him to forget it
Why does he trouble me with letters? yet I'll read 'em.
Ha? to be married tomorrow — this is an honest
Sentence, my heart bleeds still for wronging you.
Clariana 'tis no secret

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha to Eubella, I sha'not conceal my passion, he must not marry

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Give me the paper

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Inspire me love I'll cross itExit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why does thy master boy, send me this letter?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I know not sir; unless it be to certify you of his marriage?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He will marry now and live honest, heaven give him joy.
But it's not so fair to disturb my brain
That is not fully settled with his triumphs,
What is't to me? He cannot satisfy.
My injury if he should court his wife
And prevail with her
To embrace me too.
The Duke he writes, will honour his solemnity
His conscience dares not suffer him to invite
Me as his guest, why then must I be troubled
Cannot he laugh and heme and kiss his bride
But he must send me word, whose soul he has
Put miserably out of tune. Enter Clariana.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Conceal that letter from all eyes but your masters.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sirrah you shall return, and say I will die shortly.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Heaven forbid sir

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That is a kind of prayer, who bade thee thee sayo?
Then if I must live, I'll find out a hermit
That dwells within the earth or hollow tree.
A great way hence there I shall be secure
And learn to pray for I want charity — be gone boy

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Good sir talk not so strangely

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fare you well too, I'll come again tomorrow, or I know
Not when, I have much business abroad

sp.speaker: Cla,
sp.l: Will you ride forth?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Shall none attend you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No I shall be best alone, you know your chamber
There's none so bold to rob me of my grief
Yet he that's sad as I; bears his own thief.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: I know not what to resolve, this letter has distracted me it is not wisdom to acquaint Eubella, let me peruse't again. Sir, though I have repented my love, which drew my dishonour, I have not lost my charity, and therefore can take no pleasure in your ruin, meet me tomorrow early in the grove behind the palace, I will discover a plot against your life, I pity your danger, and will secure more joys to your bride, be secret yet and trust her, that is no otherwise than nobly yours, Clariana.

lg.l: For his revenge, did he speak strangely sayest?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Very strangely sir, he said he would die shortly

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p:
Thou didst mistake him, he meant I should die, he wonot kill me at the altar? perhaps I shall be poisoned at dinner, a thousand ways there are to let out life
I must be certain. Eubella and her father
Enter Eubella and Sebastian.
Some truce with my affliction.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: More welcome than my liberty, Eubella
Has made my heart glad with your new character
And now my son Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: That title
Will be above all honours the Duke can
Let fall upon me, that I have been wild
I must with shame remember, but my study
Of after life to her and all the world
I hope shall purchase thee a better name.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You will not leave us this morning?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I shall return, excuse me a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Do what you please ▪ but if it be a business
You may dispense with

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: It concerns my honour, but nothing shall
Detain me long; all places are but darkness
Without thy eyes, I'll visit 'em 'Again

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: How soon?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You shall scarce think me absent

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: We must expect you then.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: May the day shine bright upon thee

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And all the blessings of it wait on you

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Signior you are most welcome, I entreat you
To call my girl your daughter

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My son has made this choice I hear, I'll
Call her any thing

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I shall express my duty sir, in all things

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But where's Hippolito — a buxom thing.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir please you retire, he is new departed

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Whither? A musical lip.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay we did not examine his affair
But we expect his quick return

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Will't please you sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I should be pleased with such another, — a light wench
And a yare, I'll attend you lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Be just Milena to me, and endear
My love for ever

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Madam you know my faith

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I promised to meet
Hippolito this morning in the grove
Behind the palace, to confer about
Some business that concerns, thou shalt presently
Excuse my travel and entreat him hither,
He and my husband lately had some difference
I know not why, in this convenient absence
Of Bellament he securely may
Speak with me here, yet I'll not willingly
Have him come hither by the public way,
The garden door shall be left open for him
And a clear passage to this chamber

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Madam I understand,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Prevail with him to come, tell him all's safe

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: I'll swear it madam to do you service

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But use all haste.
Which way shall I begin, I shall want art
I fear to win upon him, o for some
High, and prevailing oratory to
Express what my heart labours with I could
Accuse my unkind destiny, declaim
Against the power of love, rail at the charms
Of language and proportion, that betray us
To hasty sorrow, and too late repentance,
But breath is this way lost, wounds that are made
Require a balsam, and not empty curses
To state our body, should the mariner
When a storm meets him, throw away his card
Neglect himself and vessel; and lie down
Cursing the winds and tempest? If he come
As but to doubt doth make me miserable
The genius of love assist my passion,
I must deliver something that doth make
My poor heart swell, and will if I conceal it
Like fire locked up in a thick cloud destroy
the prison that contains: she's returned
Already. Enter Milena.
What says Hippolito?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Like an honest gentleman, he's at the garden gate.
I told him how things were at home, I met him
Hard by, as if he meant without inviting
Having expected you so long, to come
Nearer, and wait some opportunity
To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thou'rt fortunate admit him, 'tis nor
Safe to expect there, but while we confer
Use thy best diligence round about to bring
If there be such misfortune, the first news
Of Bellament

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: I'll be careful madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'm glad he's come
With what look shall I first salute him?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Pray excuse me sir!

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: 'Twill purchase but a pair of gloves

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: I have him at my finger's ends, well I can but think
What serviceable creatures we chambermaids are
Sometimes we are the best cabinets for ladies, and they
Trust their jewels of honour with us, but I must look
About me, I know my office. Exit,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You've seen this face before, does it seem strange?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I have seen it, when it was less sad, but 'tis
The richer jewel set in black, you never
Wore garments did so well become you lady

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I shall not love 'em worse because they please
Your eye, they fit the habit of my mind.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Your voice has better music too, it sounds
As some religious melancholy struck.
Upon your heart you've prayed lately I distinguish
A tear upon your cheek still 'tis well done

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If there be any sign of sorrow here
'Tis for your sake

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I cannot blame thy eyes,
if every time, I am presented to 'em
Th' unhappy object thou dost weep Clariana,
I have deserved to find the lowest place
Within thy charity, yet such is thy
Compassion, when my fate is cast
And my unworthy life marked for the sacrifice
Thou art willing to preserve Hippolito
And to that purpose sentest to speak with me

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You read my letter?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Clariana, I
Shall not have time enough to thank thee, when
Thou hast discovered what conspiracy
Threatens my head, unless you use some brevity
There is a work this morning to be finished
Requires my personal attendance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am.
Not ignorant what business is designed
It was the reason of my zealous wishes
To change some words before

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I wait your purpose

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are this morning to receive a wife

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: And such blessing as the earth were poor
Without her,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis Eubella I understand.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: That most virtuous fair one

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I'll not take from her
I have heard her much commended, but she is
No miracle

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: How Clariana.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Our sex were poor
If she alone had all the grace of woman.
Though she be fair, the dukedom is not so
Barren but it may show some parallel.
And let it not be thought a pride, if I
Affirm there have been those, have said as much
Of me, all beauty is not circumscribed
In one.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: You point at that which takes the eye
and is but half a handsomeness at best
Unless the mind be furnished with those virtues
Which write a woman fair, but Clariana
There is no time for this dispute, and I
Am somewhat sorry you have fallen upon't
When I but praised Eubella modestly,
She is to me the best and fairest now
Of all the world, but turn to the occasion
That brought me hither, I would hear what practice
Is meant against my life, which I would now
Preserve for that dear virgin, more than love
To keep it for my use, I did imagine
However Bellament showed a formal
And calm release, yet he would meditate
Revenge at such a time he most should wound me
And had not I a perfect confidence
Your thoughts meant simple pity to my danger
I should not thus far have engaged myself,
Than I beseech you tell me

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Why d'ye delay me thus Clariana?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pardon oh pardon me Hippolito
Indeed I will discover all the plot

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I am prepared,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But there is no misfortune
Levelled at you, the danger is all mine
And I but use this policy, to take
My last farewell, for I must never see
You married

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: You amaze me, what unhappiness?
Will Bellament be so cruel to thee
Having forgiven

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A hand more severe.
Is armed against me

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Is there no prevention

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It is within your mercy to do much

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: Pronounce then as much safety as my strength can give thee against any enemy be
sp.l: But Bellament, I have wounded him
Too much already, may I credit then
There is treachery aiming at my blood
Declare what man I must oppose in thy
Protection

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No man

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: You're mystical

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A woman is my enemy

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: There will be
No use of valour then

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But much of love
If you resolve to save bleeding Clariana
Thou must oppose Eubella.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: What was that?
Kill my Eubella?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It stretches not so far, only I beg
You would not marry her, and I shall live.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Not marry her, why there's no steel can bring
So certain and so violent a death,
Forsake Eubella now, now when she's dressed
My glorious bride, the nuptial ceremony
And priest expecting us, I know you speak not
In hope I should believe, you may as well
Bid me'commit a murder on my life
For this will kill her and we both are one.
Who hath instructed you to this?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My love
My love that will not suffer me to know
Thou must be given thus away for ever
I could endure thy absence for whole years
And not complain, repent my equal sorrow
We have so far offended, while you keep
Your present freedom, there were then some hope
A possibility, at last to meet
In new affections to redeem the old
But thus my expectation is destroyed,
You understand?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Too much, be not deceived,
there is no love that is not virtuous
And thy consenting thus far but in thought
Is sacrilege, and thou dost rob the church
Twice, first in violation of thy vows
Which there were registered, and then mine expected
I dare not hear you talk thus

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is this all?
All the reward for losing of myself
For thy sake?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You're not yet quite lost

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What curse
Made black the hour of my conception
Farewell Hippolito, when you hear me dead
Come to my grave, and drop one tear upon me

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What means Clariana? Enter Milena.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: O madam look behind me
I see my master coming in, and he
Suspecting my haste this way, follows me
With his sword drawnEnter Bellament ▪

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Are you so nimble? ha.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Woman thou hast undone me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O my fortune again betrayed

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay then, I'll make sure workExit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Alas what shall become of me, the doors are locked.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Cruel dissembler.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hippolito the sequel shall acquit
My thoughts, I'm circled with more certain danger
And cannot hope life

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: 'Tis not that I fear
To die, thou knowest I am not guilty
Of any second shame, but my Eubella
That every minute looks to be my bride
How the thought rends me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I can prevent his fury
Against thee

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: There is no way

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes this.

sp.speaker: Hi ▪
sp.l: Ha devil what hast done?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Alas what ha' you both done?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I thank thee
Thou hast spared my execution on myself
I'll tell thee now Hippolito, by this
This crimson in whose ebb my life hasts from me
I did not look for Bellament, but
Surprised I thought it honour to beg in
The tragedy, I know my fate was not
To be resisted, 'twas impossible.
To find a second mercy from him, and
I would secure no woman after me
Should boast the conquest of Hippolito
Thy sword was gentle to me, searched again
And thou shalt see.
How my embracing blood will keep it warm
And kiss the kind destroyer

div.stage: Enter Bellament and servants, Milena runs in.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What are you humbled? must not serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We have deceived your triumph.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Bellament.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hear me first, and know this bold hand saved
Thy fury to Hippolito, whom with
My last breath I pronounce not in a thought
Guilty of new dishonour

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As soon persuade
It is not day

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: This letter summoned me

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I had no other means to speak with him
And my unruly love did prompt me to it

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: I tremble not in my innocence to think
Of death but my Eubella, poor Eubella

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If she but loud thee as I did, she'll follow
Furies will lend a torch to light her to
The shades we go to

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is the wickedness all thine?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Except the wound my hasty sword
Gave as reward for this too near my heart
I fear

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dost fear?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: For poor Eubella's sake

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now thou hast met a justice in thy blood
For thy first sin, but I will have a surgeon

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Send for Eubella rather
O let me breathe my last upon her lips
It will concern thee Bellament somewhat
The world will think this murder was thine else

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Make haste:
Oh woman thou didst weep once, when thy tears
Won my forgiveness, where are all the drops,
The penitent showers, in which thy stained soul
Should bathe itself, this minute launching forth
To thy eternity.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They're of another colour, o forgive me
Good heaven, I have wronged thee Bellament
O wives hereafter, mean your hearts to them
You give your holy vows, what mist weighs down
My eyes already, o 'tis death I see
In a long robe of darkness is preparing
To seal them up for ever, 'twere no death,
If we could lose our sins as we do breathe

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She's gone to a long silence, place her body
There and then gently raise Hippolito
To the other chair

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Hast, haste my dear Eubella. Enter Bonaldo

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How came this tragedy?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: Give me your last blessing
I'm going a long pilgrimage, you gave
Too great a licence to my youth

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.l: My wanton blood now pays fort, Clariana
And I have changed a wound, where is Eubella?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She is too near this grief, this punishment
Should ha' been mine long since, I was his father
In sin as well as years, she is dead already
Thy glass had many sands till it was broken
Then those few minutes that are left of mine,
I'll number with my prayers. Enter Duke. Eub. Seb. court.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My wound hath had a happy patience. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Eubella

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: He is departed

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Bellament who hath done all this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll do my best to tell you
Here's all that's left of them whom how I loved,
Heaven and my poor heart knows,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And is he slain?
But once more let me kiss him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I did not kill 'em sir, they were too willing
To leave the world together, but their wrongs
All all the payment for my honest love
Awaked me to revenge, and had they been
The very strings that tie my life together
It should ha' fallen to pieces, but their hands
Prevented mine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The cause? you rather lead me
To think you were their murderer, we must
Be better satisfied or your blood must answer
For this effusion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The cause my lord — 'tis grown since it came hither
Pray give me leave, because you sha'not suffer
Ith' expectation, you shall have it all
Together, this Hippolito and that Clariana
Hark there 'tis. Enter Milena.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: His grief has overcharged him

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: None to decipher these sad characters?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: With your pardon I can

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Be comforted Eubella, all thy tears
Will not recall his life

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Pray give me leave
Since he is dead to embalm him, had I died
Before him, he'd ha' wept as much for me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We have heard too much but moderate Eubella,
Thy sorrows, he survives that will supply
A bridegroom, and thy virtue bids me tender
myself a recompense for thy sufferings

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I know you would not lead me to forget
Hippolito so soon, I dare not think
Of being a bride again.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Does your grace mean this honour?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By my Duke dome.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: After this shower is over, she will shine
Doubt not my lord, and bless her happy stars

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Lead from this charnel house they shall be interred
With all solemnity becomes there birth
And when their funeral rites and tears are done
New joys shall rise with the next morning's sun.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
